intro: Oliveranthus, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its striking, bell-shaped yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters and features slender, hairy stems. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Oliveranthus thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and alpine displays.
